which is an orthodox Hecke L-series with Größencharakter ( see [ 15 ]).
Over the rational field,  the curve Fjy is 2-isogenous to
^- 4D- + ^ Dxz ^.,
the isogeny arising from the rational 2-division point ( 0,  0,  1 ) on Г.  It follows that the two curves have the same value of g,  the number of generators of infinite order of and since — 4 = ( 1 + iy they have the same iV ^^, zeta-functions and L-series.  However they need not have the same Tate-Safarevic group ; for examples see [ 2 ], § 4. 
Even though Fjy is defined over the rational field Ç,  from certain points of view its natural field of definition is the Gaussian field Q { i ). This is the least field over which the complex multiplication on Fjy is defined ; and it is the field of definition of the quartic residue symbol.  Over Ç ( i ), is birationally equivalent to F _^ jy instead of merely iso- genous.  Suppose that ^-^^ is the group of points on Fjy defined over Q { i ) y where we still assume D to be rational.  In virtue of the complex multiplication on we can regard as a Z ( i )- module ; and it then has as many generators of infinite order as does regarded as a Z-module.  We prove no relations between the various Tate-Safarevic groups involved,  though some are implicit in our conjectures ; clearly the Tate-Safarevic groups of Fj ) and F _^ j ^ can only differ in their 2-components. 
It remains to consider the zeta-function of F over Q ( i ); and here it costs nothing to take L to be a Gaussian integer.  If p = 3 ( mod 4 ) is a rational prime then
